Child Enrollment Documentation Training

Presenter: Jonathan Dudzik

Module Objectives

  1. List the types of institutions that require enrollment documentation
  2. Identify enrollment documentation regulations and requirements
  3. Identify the NC CACFP Child Participant Enrollment Form
  4. And accurately assess enrollment documentation

Child Care Requirements

Which child care programs need enrollment documentation?

All types of centers require enrollment documentation except for emergency shelters and at-risk afterschool care centers.

Good
to
know!

Examples of institutions that need enrollment documentation:

  1. Licensed centers
  2. Preschools
  3. Head Start Programs
  4. Day care homes

Important! If an outside-school-hours care center is operated as part of a child care center that participates in the CACFP, it will require CACFP enrollment documentation.

Source: USDA: 7CFR Part 226

Enrollment Documentation Requirements

Some institutions are exempt from collecting CACFP Enrollment documentation.

Before we talk about them, click the next button to test your knowledge of what we have covered so far!

Requirements: At-risk Afterschool Care

At‐risk afterschool programs do have to keep the following records daily:

  1. Names of participants (daily roster)
  2. Number of snacks or meals delivered
  3. Number of snacks or meals served

Requirements: Emergency Shelters

Emergency Shelters do not have to maintain CACFP enrollment documentation for children.

At minimum, they need to keep a list with each child's name, date of birth, and dates of residency in the shelter!

Good
to
know!

Additional Requirement
for at-risk-afterschool meals:

Emergency shelters must ensure that only meals served to eligible resident children are claimed. Also, note that meals served to adults & non‐resident children are not reimbursable.

Source: USDA: 7CFR Part 226

Requirements: Outside-School-Hours Care

Centers that operate outside-school-hours care centers must keep the following documentation:

  1. Names of participants
  2. Attendance records
  3. Daily meal counts

Remember, if an outside-school-hours care center is operated as part of a child care center that participates in the CACFP, it will require CACFP enrollment documentation.

Test Your Knowledge!

{{ quizModalBody }}

Enrollment Documentation Regulations

Why do child care programs need enrollment documentation?

… It’s in the regulations!

Good
to
know!

What we mean when we talk about "The regulations".

The Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) is the codification of general and permanent rules published in the Federal Register by the departments and agencies of the Federal Government produced by the Office of the Federal Register and the Government Publishing Office.

Source: USDA: 7CFR Part 226

Enrollment Documentation Regulations

Click on the large yellow buttons to read the regulations are related to child enrollment documentation requirements!

7 CFR 226.15 (e)

7 CFR 226.10 (d)

7 CFR 226.15 (e)

"Each institution shall establish procedures to collect and maintain all program records required under this part as well as any records required by the State agency. Failure to maintain such records shall be grounds for the denial of reimbursement (...) Such documentation of enrollment must be updated annually, signed by a parent or legal guardian, and include information on each child's normal days and hours of care and the meals normally received while in care."

Source: USDA: 7CFR Part 226

7 CFR 226.10 (d)

"All records to support the claim shall be retained for a period of three years after the date of submission of the final claim for the fiscal year to which they pertain, except that if audit findings have not been resolved, the records shall be retained beyond the end of the three year period as long as may be required for the resolution of the issues raised by the audit. All accounts and records pertaining to the Program shall be made available, upon request, to representatives of the State agency"

Source: USDA: 7CFR Part 226

Enrollment Documentation Key Points

  1. Must be Kept on file
  2. Include each child's normal days and hours of care
  3. Include meals normally received while in care
  4. Must be signed by a parent or guardian
  5. Must be updated annually
  6. Must be kept confidential
  7. Retain for three years plus the current fiscal year

Review an enrollment
form - Senario #1:

Click in the section that is missing information.

Correct! Joe’s enrollment documentation is missing the information on his living arrangement. This makes the documentation invalid. Joe’s meals cannot be claimed until the enrollment documentation is returned to the participant and completed.

That is not correct. Try again...

Review an enrollment
form - Senario #2:

Click in the section that is missing information.

Correct! Because John is under the age of 60, the enrollment documentation must indicate if he is a “functionally impaired adult.” This box needs to be checked for any adult day care participant under the age of 60. As in the previous example, John’s meals cannot be claimed until the enrollment documentation is returned to the participant or their guardian and completed.

That is not correct. Try again...
